articles.headline: The Facebook Fallacy: Privacy Is Up to You
articles.snippet: Mark Zuckerberg told Congress that the social network would empower its users to control their own data. There’s just one problem: human behavior.
articles.abstract: Mark Zuckerberg told Congress that the social network would empower its users to control their own data. There’s just one problem: human behavior.
articles.lead_paragraph: Was Mark Zuckerberg pulling their leg?

articles.headline: Jeff Sessions Is Serving, and Doing His Best to Ignore, Trump
articles.snippet: Crisscrossing the nation, the embattled attorney general praises the president for supporting law enforcement — most law enforcement, anyway.
articles.abstract: Crisscrossing the nation, the embattled attorney general praises the president for supporting law enforcement — most law enforcement, anyway.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAS CRUCES, N.M. — On an oven-hot day this month, Attorney General Jeff Sessions strode into a hotel ballroom to preach Trump-era immigration gospel to cowboy-hatted sheriffs from 31 counties near the United States’ border with Mexico.

articles.headline: British Citizen One Day, Illegal Immigrant the Next
articles.snippet: The “Windrush generation” — Caribbeans invited to Britain to help rebuild after World War II — has faced harsh treatment under a migration crackdown.
articles.abstract: The “Windrush generation” — Caribbeans invited to Britain to help rebuild after World War II — has faced harsh treatment under a migration crackdown.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Renford McIntyre was just a child when he left Jamaica to join his parents in Britain.

articles.headline: Mulvaney, Watchdog Bureau’s Leader, Advises Bankers on Ways to Curtail Agency
articles.snippet: Mick Mulvaney, acting director of the bureau, also described the two types of people he was most responsive to as a lawmaker: constituents and the lobbyists who contributed to his campaign.
articles.abstract: Mick Mulvaney, acting director of the bureau, also described the two types of people he was most responsive to as a lawmaker: constituents and the lobbyists who contributed to his campaign.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Mick Mulvaney, the interim director of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, told banking industry executives on Tuesday that they should press lawmakers hard to pursue their agenda, and revealed that, as a congressman, he would meet with lobbyists only if they had contributed to his campaign.

articles.headline: Workers of Silicon Valley, It’s Time to Organize
articles.snippet: Employees in the tech industry have an unusual power: They can make their companies act more responsibly. All they have to do is speak up.
articles.abstract: Employees in the tech industry have an unusual power: They can make their companies act more responsibly. All they have to do is speak up.

articles.headline: Don Blankenship Is a West Virginia Senate Candidate. He Lives in Nevada.
articles.snippet: The former coal mining executive, a strong supporter of President Trump who is running as an “American competitionist,” has refused to disclose his personal finances as required by law.
articles.abstract: The former coal mining executive, a strong supporter of President Trump who is running as an “American competitionist,” has refused to disclose his personal finances as required by law.
articles.lead_paragraph: KEYSER, W.Va. — Don Blankenship is running for the United States Senate as a proud West Virginian with Appalachian roots, but his primary residence is a $2.4 million villa with palm trees and an infinity pool near Las Vegas.
articles.byline: By Trip Gabriel and Stephanie Saul

articles.headline: Key Justices Seem Skeptical of Challenge to Trump’s Travel Ban
articles.snippet: By the end of the argument, the Supreme Court’s conservative majority seemed ready to defer to the president’s national security judgments and discount his campaign promises to impose a “Muslim ban.”
articles.abstract: By the end of the argument, the Supreme Court’s conservative majority seemed ready to defer to the president’s national security judgments and discount his campaign promises to impose a “Muslim ban.”
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A 15-month legal battle over President Trump’s efforts to impose a ban on travel to the United States from several predominantly Muslim countries reached a final stage on Wednesday at the Supreme Court, with its five-member conservative majority signaling it was ready to approve a revised version of the president’s plan.
articles.byline: By Adam Liptak and Michael D. Shear

articles.headline: Search for ‘Golden State Killer’ Leads to Arrest of Ex-Cop
articles.snippet: Joseph James DeAngelo, 72, is the suspect in the case of a serial killer and rapist who terrorized communities in California in the 1970s and 1980s.
articles.abstract: Joseph James DeAngelo, 72, is the suspect in the case of a serial killer and rapist who terrorized communities in California in the 1970s and 1980s.
articles.lead_paragraph: SACRAMENTO — It was a rash of sadistic rapes and murders that spread terror throughout California, long before the term was commonly used. The scores of attacks in the 1970s and 1980s went unsolved for more than three decades. But on Wednesday, law enforcement officials said they had finally arrested the notorious Golden State Killer in a tidy suburb of Sacramento.
articles.byline: By Thomas Fuller and Christine Hauser
